description: From Middle English doppe, from Old English *doppa (“dipper”), as in Old English dūfedoppa (“pelican”).
From Middle English doppen, from Old English *doppian (“to dip, dive, plunge”), related to Old English doppettan (“to dip, dip in, immerse”).

verbs.description: dop (third-person singular simple present dops, present participle dopping, simple past and past participle dopped)

entries.meaning: (South Africa, slang) To fail or to plug (an examination, standard or grade)

description: From Dutch dop, from Middle Dutch dop, dup, doppe, from Old Dutch *dopp, *dupp, from Proto-West Germanic *dupp, from Proto-Germanic *duppaz (“hollow, shell, bowl”). Cognate with Saterland Frisian Dop (“shell, pod, bowl”), German Topf (“pot”).

examples: Let's go to the bar for a dop.

entries.meaning: (South Africa, slang) An imprecise measure of alcohol; a dash.
examples: Give me a dop of brandy.

entries.meaning: (diamond-cutting) A little copper cup in which a diamond is held while being cut.

verbs.description: dop (third-person singular simple present dops, present participle dopping, simple past and past participle dopped)

examples: They not only forswore dopping themselves, but also contrived to make the National Party forgo a dop.
